abstract.text: Sets the style for toggles in a view hierarchy.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The toggle style to set. Use one of the built-in
or a custom style that you define by creating a type that conforms
A view that uses the specified toggle style for itself
instance to set a style that defines
the control’s appearance and behavior. For example, you can choose
Built-in styles typically have a similar appearance across platforms,
tailored to the platform’s overall style:
You can set a style for all toggle instances within a view hierarchy
by applying the style modifier to a container view. For example, you
The example above has the following appearance when
If you don’t set a style, SwiftUI assumes a value of
default. Specify the automatic style explicitly to override a
container’s style and revert to the default:

code: .toggleStyle(.button) // Use button style for toggles in the stack.
.labelStyle(.iconOnly) // Omit the title from any labels.

inlineContent.text: The style that SwiftUI uses as the default depends on both the platform
and the context. In macOS, the default in most contexts is a
, while in iOS, the default toggle style is a
Like toggle style does for toggles, the
which is useful for button toggles in space-constrained contexts.
Always include a descriptive title for better accessibility.
For more information about how SwiftUI chooses a default toggle style,

SwiftUI-PageImage-card.png.alt: A black Swift logo on a swirly blue and purple background.

View-toggleStyle-1-iOS.alt: A screenshot of the text Vibrate on Ring appearing to the left of a toggle switch that’s on. The toggle’s tint color is green. The toggle and its text appear in a rounded rectangle.

View-toggleStyle-1-macOS.alt: A screenshot of the text Vibrate on Ring appearing to the left of a toggle switch that’s on. The toggle’s tint color is blue. The toggle and its text appear on a neutral background.

View-toggleStyle-2-iOS.alt: A screenshot of two buttons arranged horizontally. The first has the image of a flag and is active with a blue tint. The second has an image of a speaker with a line through it and is inactive with a neutral tint.

View-toggleStyle-2-macOS.alt: A screenshot of two buttons arranged horizontally. The first has the image of a flag and is active with a blue tint. The second has an image of a speaker with a line through it and is inactive with a neutral tint.

View-toggleStyle-3-iOS.alt: A screenshot of several horizontally arranged items: two buttons, a vertical divider line, the text Enhance sound, and a switch. The first button has two right facing arrows that cross over in the middle and is active with a blue tint. The second button has one right and one left facing arrow and is inactive with neutral tint. The switch is on and has a green tint.

View-toggleStyle-3-macOS.alt: A screenshot of several horizontally arranged items: two buttons, a vertical divider line, a checkbox, and the text Enhance sound. The first button has two right facing arrows that cross over in the middle and is active with a blue tint. The second button has one right and one left facing arrow and is inactive with a neutral tint. The check box is checked and has a blue tint.

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
A view that arranges its subviews in a horizontal line.
A standard label for user interface items, consisting of an icon with a
A label style that only displays the icon of the label.
A control for selecting a value from a bounded linear range of values.
A control that performs increment and decrement actions.
A control that toggles between on and off states.
The appearance and behavior of a toggle.
A toggle style that displays as a button with its label as the title.
A toggle style that displays a checkbox followed by its label.
A toggle style that displays a leading label and a trailing switch.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
Sets the style for labels within this view.
Sets the style for toggles in a view hierarchy.
